article.title: Quenches from gaussian bosons to Tonks-Girardeau gas: stationary states and effects of a confining potential

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 (Left) shows the stationary fermionic two-point correlation function after a quench from a thermal state to the Tonks-Girardeau limit. What happens to the decay behavior of this correlation function as the temperature approaches zero?
choices: The decay remains exponential.
The decay becomes algebraic.
The decay becomes oscillatory.
The decay vanishes entirely.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 2 (Center), what distinguishes the stationary momentum density distribution of the fermions after the quench from a thermal distribution at finite temperature?
choices: It is non-analytic for all momenta.
It is analytic for all momenta.
It is symmetric around k=0.
It shows sharp peaks at specific momenta.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 (Right) depicts the stationary bosonic two-point correlation function after the quench. What is the main difference observed between this correlation function and the fermionic one shown in Figure 2 (Left)?
choices: The bosonic correlation decays algebraically, while the fermionic one decays exponentially.
The bosonic correlation decays exponentially, while the fermionic one decays algebraically.
Both correlations decay exponentially, but with different decay rates.
Both correlations decay algebraically, but with different power laws.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 compares the time evolution of the Wigner distribution for a harmonic trap (top row) and an anharmonic trap (bottom row). What is the key difference in their long-time behavior?
choices: The Wigner function in the harmonic trap relaxes to a stationary distribution, while it continues to evolve periodically in the anharmonic trap.
The Wigner function in the anharmonic trap relaxes to a stationary distribution, while it continues to evolve periodically in the harmonic trap.
Both Wigner functions relax to stationary distributions, but with different shapes.
Both Wigner functions exhibit persistent oscillations without reaching a stationary state.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation (24) relates the density-density correlator in the steady state to the two-point fermionic correlator. What does this equation imply about the decay rate of the density-density correlator compared to the fermionic correlator?
choices: The density-density correlator decays at the same rate as the fermionic correlator.
The density-density correlator decays at half the rate of the fermionic correlator.
The density-density correlator decays at twice the rate of the fermionic correlator.
The density-density correlator does not decay, while the fermionic correlator does.
